postrequisite_ids: Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_Domain, Codomain and Range

Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set.problem: What is the definition of a set in mathematics?
Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set.solution: A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects.

Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set.problem: What notation is used to denote a set?
Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set.solution: Curly brackets {} are used to denote a set, with elements separated by commas.
A finite set is a set that has a finite number of elements.

Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set.problem: What is an infinite set? Give an example.
Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set.solution: An infinite set is a set with an infinite number of elements. For example, the set of all natural numbers {1, 2, 3, ...} is an infinite set.

prerequisite_ids: Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set Definitions And Notations

Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Union.problem: What is the union of two sets A and B?
Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Union.solution: The union of sets A and B, denoted A ∪ B, is the set of all elements that are in A or in B or in both.

Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Union.problem: What is the intersection of two sets A and B?
Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Union.solution: The intersection of sets A and B, denoted A ∩ B, is the set of all elements that are in both A and B.

Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Venn D.solution: A Venn diagram is a pictorial representation of the relationships between sets, often using overlapping circles.

Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Venn D.problem: In a Venn diagram representing sets A and B, what does the overlapping region represent?
Understanding Sets_Set Operations_Venn D.solution: The overlapping region in a Venn diagram of sets A and B represents the intersection of A and B, i.e., elements that are in both sets.

Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.solution: A complex number is a number that can be expressed in the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers, and i is the imaginary unit defined as the square root of -1.

Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.problem: What is the imaginary unit denoted by and what is its property?
Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.solution: The imaginary unit is denoted by i and it is defined by the property i^2 = -1.

prerequisite_ids: Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Number Basics_Definition And Notation

Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.problem: For the complex number z = 3 - 4i, what is the real part?
Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.solution: The real part of the complex number z = 3 - 4i is 3.

Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.problem: For the complex number z = 2 + 7i, what is the imaginary part?
Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Numbe.solution: The imaginary part of the complex number z = 2 + 7i is 7.

prerequisite_ids: Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Number Basics_Definition And Notation
Complex Numbers Operations_Complex Number Arithmetic_Multiplication and Division_1

postrequisite_ids: Functions And Mappings_Types Of Functions_Injective, Surjective, Bijective

Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_F.problem: What is a function in mathematics?
Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_F.solution: A function is a relation between a set of inputs (domain) and a set of outputs (codomain) where each input is related to exactly one output.

Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_F.problem: What is the vertical line test and what does it determine?
Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_F.solution: The vertical line test is a visual way to determine if a curve represents a function. If any vertical line intersects the curve more than once, the curve does not represent a function.

prerequisite_ids: Understanding Sets_Set Theory Basics_Set Definitions And Notations

Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_D.problem: What is the domain of a function?
Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_D.solution: The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values (x-values) for which the function is defined.

Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_D.problem: What is the difference between the codomain and range of a function?
Functions And Mappings_Function Basics_D.solution: The codomain of a function is the set of all possible output values, while the range is the set of actual output values. The range is always a subset of the codomain.

Functions And Mappings_Types Of Function.solution: An injective function is a function where every element of the codomain is mapped to by at most one element of the domain. In other words, no two distinct elements of the domain map to the same element in the codomain.
A surjective function is a function where every element of the codomain is mapped to by at least one element of the domain. In other words, the range and codomain of the function are equal.
An even function is a function that satisfies the condition f(-x) = f(x) for all x in the domain of f.
An odd function is a function that satisfies the condition f(-x) = -f(x) for all x in the domain of f.

Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.problem: What is the standard form of a quadratic equation?
Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.solution: The standard form of a quadratic equation is ax^2 + bx + c = 0, where a, b, and c are real numbers and a ≠ 0.

Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.problem: In the standard form of a quadratic equation ax^2 + bx + c = 0, what does the value of a determine about the parabola?
Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.solution: In the standard form ax^2 + bx + c = 0, the value of a determines the direction of the parabola. If a > 0, the parabola opens upward. If a < 0, the parabola opens downward.

Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.problem: What is the vertex form of a quadratic function?
Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.solution: The vertex form of a quadratic function is f(x) = a(x - h)^2 + k, where (h, k) is the vertex of the parabola.

Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.problem: In the vertex form f(x) = a(x - h)^2 + k, what do h and k represent?
Quadratic Functions_Quadratic Equations_.solution: In the vertex form f(x) = a(x - h)^2 + k, h represents the x-coordinate and k represents the y-coordinate of the vertex of the parabola.

Quadratic Functions_Solving Quadratic Eq.problem: What is the first step in solving a quadratic equation by factoring?
Quadratic Functions_Solving Quadratic Eq.solution: The first step in solving a quadratic equation by factoring is to set the equation equal to zero and express it in standard form: ax^2 + bx + c = 0.

Quadratic Functions_Solving Quadratic Eq.problem: After factoring a quadratic equation, how do you find the solutions?
Quadratic Functions_Solving Quadratic Eq.solution: After factoring a quadratic equation into the form (ax + b)(cx + d) = 0, the solutions are found by setting each factor equal to zero and solving for x. This gives the solutions x = -b/a and x = -d/c.
The quadratic formula is x = (-b ± √(b^2 - 4ac)) / (2a), where a, b, and c are the coefficients of a quadratic equation in standard form (ax^2 + bx + c = 0).

Quadratic Functions_Solving Quadratic Eq.problem: Under what condition does a quadratic equation have no real solutions?
Quadratic Functions_Solving Quadratic Eq.solution: A quadratic equation has no real solutions when the discriminant (b^2 - 4ac) is less than zero. In this case, the solutions are complex numbers.

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions, arranged in rows and columns.

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.problem: How is the size of a matrix described?
Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: The size of a matrix is described by the number of rows and columns it contains. An m x n matrix has m rows and n columns.

prerequisite_ids: Matrix Operations And Applications_Matrix Basics_Definition and Notation

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: A square matrix is a matrix with the same number of rows and columns, i.e., an n x n matrix.
An identity matrix is a square matrix where all elements on the main diagonal are 1 and all other elements are 0. It is denoted by I.
prerequisite_ids: Matrix Operations And Applications_Matrix Basics_Types of Matrices_1

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.problem: Under what condition can two matrices be added or subtracted?
Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: Two matrices can be added or subtracted only if they have the same dimensions, i.e., the same number of rows and columns.

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.problem: How do you add or subtract two matrices?
Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: To add or subtract two matrices, add or subtract corresponding elements. (A ± B)_ij = A_ij ± B_ij.
prerequisite_ids: Matrix Operations And Applications_Matrix Operations_Addition and Subtraction_1

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.problem: What is the condition for matrix multiplication?
Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: For matrix multiplication AB, the number of columns in A must equal the number of rows in B.

Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.problem: What are the dimensions of the product matrix AB?
Matrix Operations And Applications_Matri.solution: If A is an m x n matrix and B is an n x p matrix, then the product AB is an m x p matrix.

Sequences And Series_Sequences_Definitio.problem: What is a sequence in mathematics?
Sequences And Series_Sequences_Definitio.solution: A sequence is an ordered list of numbers. It is usually denoted by {a_n}, where a_n is the n-th term of the sequence.

Sequences And Series_Sequences_Definitio.problem: What is the difference between a finite and an infinite sequence?
Sequences And Series_Sequences_Definitio.solution: A finite sequence has a last term, while an infinite sequence continues indefinitely.

postrequisite_ids: Sequences And Series_Series_Arithmetic and Geometric Series

Sequences And Series_Sequences_Arithmeti.solution: An arithmetic sequence is a sequence where the difference between the consecutive terms is constant. This constant difference is called the common difference.
A geometric sequence is a sequence where each term after the first is found by multiplying the previous term by a fixed, non-zero number called the common ratio.

Sequences And Series_Series_Definition a.problem: What is a series in mathematics?
Sequences And Series_Series_Definition a.solution: A series is the sum of the terms of a sequence. It is usually denoted by Σ a_n, where a_n is the n-th term of the sequence.

Sequences And Series_Series_Definition a.problem: What is a partial sum of a series?
Sequences And Series_Series_Definition a.solution: A partial sum of a series is the sum of a finite number of consecutive terms, starting from the first term. The n-th partial sum is denoted by s_n.

prerequisite_ids: Sequences And Series_Sequences_Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences

Sequences And Series_Series_Arithmetic a.problem: What is the formula for the sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic series?
Sequences And Series_Series_Arithmetic a.solution: The sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic series is S_n = (n/2) * [2a + (n-1)d], where a is the first term and d is the common difference.

Sequences And Series_Series_Arithmetic a.problem: What is the formula for the sum of the first n terms of a geometric series?
Sequences And Series_Series_Arithmetic a.solution: The sum of the first n terms of a geometric series is S_n = [a(1 - r^n)] / (1 - r), where a is the first term and r is the common ratio, if r ≠ 1.
prerequisite_ids: Sequences And Series_Series_Arithmetic and Geometric Series_1

Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.solution: A permutation is an arrangement of objects in a definite order.

Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.problem: What does the notation nPr represent?
Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.solution: The notation nPr represents the number of permutations of n objects taken r at a time.

Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.problem: What is the formula for nPr?
Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.solution: The formula for nPr is nPr = n! / (n-r)!, where n! is the factorial of n.

Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.problem: How many ways can 5 people be arranged in a line?
Permutations And Combinations_Permutatio.solution: This is the same as the number of permutations of 5 objects, which is 5P5 = 5! = 5 * 4 * 3 * 2 * 1 = 120.

Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.solution: A combination is a way of selecting items from a collection, such that the order of selection does not matter.

Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.problem: What does the notation nCr represent?
Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.solution: The notation nCr represents the number of combinations of n objects taken r at a time.

Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.problem: What is the formula for nCr?
Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.solution: The formula for nCr is nCr = n! / [r!(n-r)!], where n! is the factorial of n.

Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.problem: In how many ways can a committee of 3 be chosen from a group of 10 people?
Permutations And Combinations_Combinatio.solution: This is the same as the number of combinations of 10 objects taken 3 at a time, which is 10C3 = 10! / [3!(10-3)!] = 120.

Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial E.solution: The Binomial Theorem is a way of expanding expressions of the form (a + b)^n. It states that (a + b)^n = nC0 * a^n * b^0 + nC1 * a^(n-1) * b^1 + nC2 * a^(n-2) * b^2 + ... + nCn * a^0 * b^n.

Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial E.problem: What is the exponent of a and b in the (r+1)th term of the expansion (a + b)^n?
Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial E.solution: In the (r+1)th term of the expansion (a + b)^n, the exponent of a is n-r and the exponent of b is r.

Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.solution: A binomial coefficient is the coefficient of any term in the expansion of (a + b)^n. It is denoted by nCr or (n choose r).

Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.problem: What does the notation (n choose r) represent?
Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.solution: The notation (n choose r) represents the number of ways to choose r objects from n objects, where the order of selection doesn't matter. It is the same as nCr.
prerequisite_ids: Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial Coefficients_Definition and Notation_1

Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.problem: What is the value of nC0?
Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.solution: nC0 = 1 for all n ≥ 0. This is because there is only one way to choose 0 objects from n objects.

Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.problem: What is the relationship between nCr and nC(n-r)?
Binomial Theorem Applications_Binomial C.solution: nCr = nC(n-r) for all n and r. This is known as the symmetry property of binomial coefficients.

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.problem: What are the two axes in a Cartesian coordinate system?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.solution: The two axes in a Cartesian coordinate system are the x-axis (horizontal axis) and the y-axis (vertical axis).

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.problem: How many quadrants does the Cartesian coordinate system have?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.solution: The Cartesian coordinate system has four quadrants, numbered from I to IV in a counterclockwise direction starting from the top-right quadrant.

prerequisite_ids: Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coordinate System_Axes and Quadrants
postrequisite_ids: Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circle

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.problem: How is a point represented in the Cartesian coordinate system?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.solution: A point in the Cartesian coordinate system is represented by an ordered pair of numbers (x, y), where x is the point's x-coordinate (its horizontal position) and y is the point's y-coordinate (its vertical position).

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.problem: What are the coordinates of the origin?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coo.solution: The origin is the point where the x-axis and y-axis intersect. It has the coordinates (0, 0).
prerequisite_ids: Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coordinate System_Points and Coordinates_1

postrequisite_ids: Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Equation of a Line

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Slope_1.problem: What does the slope of a line represent?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Slope_1.solution: The slope of a line represents the steepness and direction of the line. It is the change in y divided by the change in x between any two points on the line.

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Slope_2.problem: How do you calculate the slope between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2)?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Slope_2.solution: The slope between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) is calculated as (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1).

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Equatio.problem: What is the slope-intercept form of a line?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Equatio.solution: The slope-intercept form of a line is y = mx + b, where m is the slope of the line and b is the y-intercept (the point where the line crosses the y-axis).

Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Equatio.problem: What is the point-slope form of a line?
Coordinate Geometry Basics_Lines_Equatio.solution: The point-slope form of a line is y - y1 = m(x - x1), where m is the slope of the line and (x1, y1) is a point on the line.

prerequisite_ids: Coordinate Geometry Basics_Cartesian Coordinate System_Points and Coordinates

Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.problem: What is the standard form of the equation of a circle?
Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.solution: The standard form of the equation of a circle is (x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2, where (h, k) is the center of the circle and r is the radius.

Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.problem: What is the equation of a circle with center (2, -3) and radius 5?
Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.solution: Using the standard form (x - h)^2 + (y - k)^2 = r^2, the equation is (x - 2)^2 + (y - (-3))^2 = 5^2, which simplifies to (x - 2)^2 + (y + 3)^2 = 25.
prerequisite_ids: Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circle_Standard Form_1
Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circle_Standard Form

Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.problem: What is the general form of the equation of a circle?
Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.solution: The general form of the equation of a circle is x^2 + y^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0, where D, E, and F are constants.

Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.problem: How can you find the center and radius of a circle from its general form equation?
Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circl.solution: If the general form equation is x^2 + y^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0, the center is (-D/2, -E/2) and the radius is sqrt((D^2 + E^2)/4 - F).
prerequisite_ids: Circle And Equations_Equation of a Circle_General Form_1

Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.problem: In a right-angled triangle, what is the sine of an angle?
Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.solution: In a right-angled triangle, the sine of an angle is the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the length of the hypotenuse.

Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.problem: In a right-angled triangle, what is the cosine of an angle?
Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.solution: In a right-angled triangle, the cosine of an angle is the ratio of the length of the adjacent side to the length of the hypotenuse.

prerequisite_ids: Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonometric Ratios_Sine, Cosine, Tangent

Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.problem: What is the reciprocal of sine?
Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.solution: The reciprocal of sine is cosecant (csc). csc(θ) = 1 / sin(θ).

Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.problem: What is the reciprocal of cosine?
Trigonometric Functions_Basic Trigonomet.solution: The reciprocal of cosine is secant (sec). sec(θ) = 1 / cos(θ).

Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.problem: What is the Pythagorean identity relating sine and cosine?
Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.solution: The Pythagorean identity relating sine and cosine is sin^2(θ) + cos^2(θ) = 1.

Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.problem: What is the Pythagorean identity relating tangent and secant?
Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.solution: The Pythagorean identity relating tangent and secant is tan^2(θ) + 1 = sec^2(θ).

Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.problem: What is the sum identity for sine?
Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.solution: The sum identity for sine is sin(α + β) = sin(α)cos(β) + cos(α)sin(β).

Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.problem: What is the difference identity for cosine?
Trigonometric Functions_Trigonometric Id.solution: The difference identity for cosine is cos(α - β) = cos(α)cos(β) + sin(α)sin(β).

Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.problem: What is a population in statistics?
Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.solution: In statistics, a population is the entire pool from which a statistical sample is drawn. It can be any complete set of people, animals, plants, or objects.

Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.problem: What is a sample in statistics?
Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.solution: In statistics, a sample is a subset of a population. It is a set of individuals or objects collected in a way that represents the larger population.

Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.problem: What is a variable in statistics?
Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.solution: In statistics, a variable is any characteristic, number, or quantity that can be measured or counted. It is called a variable because the value may vary between data units in a population.

Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.problem: What are the two main types of variables in statistics?
Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concept.solution: The two main types of variables in statistics are quantitative (numerical) variables and qualitative (categorical) variables. Quantitative variables take numerical values, while qualitative variables take non-numerical values.
prerequisite_ids: Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concepts_Variables and Data Types_1

Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.solution: A frequency table is a way of organizing raw data in a compact form by displaying a series of scores in ascending or descending order, together with their frequencies (the number of times each score occurs in the respective data set).

Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.problem: What is a relative frequency table?
Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.solution: A relative frequency table is a frequency table where each frequency is divided by the total frequency and expressed as a fraction or percentage. It shows the proportion of data points that have each score value.

Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.problem: What are some common graphical representations of data?
Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.solution: Some common graphical representations of data include bar graphs, histograms, pie charts, line graphs, and scatter plots. Each is suited for different types of data and different purposes.

Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.problem: What type of data are bar graphs best suited for?
Introduction To Statistics_Data Represen.solution: Bar graphs are best suited for categorical data, where the heights of the bars represent the frequencies or values for different categories.

prerequisite_ids: Introduction To Statistics_Basic Concepts_Variables and Data Types

Data Representation & Analysis_Data Type.solution: Quantitative data is data that can be quantified, verified, and conveyed with numbers. It can be discrete (countable values) or continuous (measurable values).

Data Representation & Analysis_Data Type.problem: What is the difference between discrete and continuous quantitative data?
Data Representation & Analysis_Data Type.solution: Discrete quantitative data can only take certain values (usually integers), often as a result of counting. Continuous quantitative data can take any value within a range, often as a result of measuring.
Qualitative data is data that cannot be expressed as a number. It is categorical in nature and describes qualities or characteristics.

Data Representation & Analysis_Data Type.problem: What are the two main types of qualitative data?
Data Representation & Analysis_Data Type.solution: The two main types of qualitative data are nominal data (unordered categories) and ordinal data (ordered categories).

Data Representation & Analysis_Graphical.solution: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. It is similar to a bar graph, but a histogram groups numbers into ranges.

Data Representation & Analysis_Graphical.problem: What type of data are histograms used for?
Data Representation & Analysis_Graphical.solution: Histograms are used to display the distribution of continuous data. They are useful when you want to see how frequently data occurs within certain ranges of values.

A box plot (also called a box-and-whisker plot) is a standardized way of displaying the distribution of data based on five number summary: minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum.

Data Representation & Analysis_Graphical.problem: What information does a box plot provide about a dataset?
Data Representation & Analysis_Graphical.solution: A box plot provides information about a dataset's median, quartiles, and outliers. It can show whether a dataset is symmetric or skewed, and how tightly the data is grouped.
